item.title: runrunzi的2023年终总结
item.description:
前言

只有时常回过头看走过的路，才能更好的迈向远方。 – runrunzi 不知不觉一年又过去了，此时的我一个人坐在电脑前，孤零零地写着年终总结，（😭原来大家跨年都有人陪，只有我还是一个人。 不是很想写流水账，就分成几个模块来写吧。想了想，打算这么分

  • 总的来说
  • 工作&技术
  • 生活
  • 展望&规划

总的来说

今年是我人生中很关键的一年，这一年会大致决定我未来的去向，未来到底要做什么。我的步调可以说是一半学，一半摆。身边的朋友有的去USA读PHD，有的去阿里这种大厂追梦，而我也在犹豫中慢慢向前摸索自己未来的路。

一年一瞬间就过去了，可能未来大概率是要去继续出国读个书的。今年最大的收获可能就是明白没有简单的路吧，体验了工业界和学术界后，有了些感觉，这些写在下面的段落中。

工作&技术

今年的开始是从一份实习开始的，我十分感谢这份实习，在这次实习中我学到了很多东西，体会到了前阿里云顶级sec团队的工作氛围（吹就完了）。

工作

Eagle Cloud Internship

今年过年面试了亿格云公司，感谢Y4👴的推荐，直接把我推到了叶总面前。面我的是刘师傅（诸多src前几名，传闻俩月挖洞挖了辆宝马）这次面试回想起来，我只想用灾难二字形容。

  • 简单说几个NLP相关算法，（🤔️
  • 简单说一次你的渗透经历，（🤔️
  • 等等等等，我只会–🤔️ 可能是我是短期实习，感谢贵司还是给了我实习的机会。 在这里呆了俩月，学到了很多业务上的能力，也明白了一些事情：
  • 功能上线前不可能总让你完全准备好，先做起来。
  • 很多业务是你根本没接触过的，这时候就需要你快速学习的能力。 实习了两个月，我感觉自己还是更向往学术界一些，工业界可能对我这种不安分的人来说有点boring，加上学校一堆课，就回到了学校。
ISCAS Intership

回到学校，就立刻进入到了找暑期实习的状态。三月到五月面了一堆公司，这里挂一下当时的emo推。

五月份投了ISCAS的系统安全实习生，没想到顺利的通过了之后就开启了直到今天的“科研”实习。

可以说，这段实习让我对安全，科研都有了新的认知。

七月份到十月份，疯狂的读了很多fuzz相关的论文，感觉打开了新世界（以前甚至肤浅的觉得sec的科研有点花拳绣腿的感觉，不是很实用）。现在发现，学术界才是引领sec发展的最前线。

感谢导让我自己负责一个项目，一直坐到今天，也快有了结果。

技术

今年技术感觉没啥大的进步，但由于GPT的出现，加上学校里的成，我更深入地去了解了一些NLP的相关知识，也去实践了一些AI和安全相关的东西。最大的进步还是入坑了FUZZ领域吧，还是要继续加油啊，小Hao！

此外还被西北大学的xing教授拉去帮忙AIXCC比赛，希望以后有机会去USA读个PHD。

生活（情感）

今年的生活可以说是有滋有味了，从小Hao的qq空间可以看出来。

此外，今年最大的突破可以说是开始了健身。自己的身体摆了两年，今年终于开始要健身了，目前已经健身了一个月，自我感觉良好，从刚开始10kg的哑铃都做不动到现在可以挑战17.5kg，进步还是肉眼可见的哈。

情感方面，本人目前单身，欢迎来打扰o.o

展望&规划

关于留学：申请ing，没啥好说的

我是想读个master当gap year然后考虑下去学术界还是工业界。如果没有合适的奥佛，我就打算做一年科研助理直接去学术界了，毕竟master对读博也没啥大用。

前两天和梁兄（一位在USA追梦的PHD）交流了一下，我跟他说，我萌生了Gap Year的想法，他也是很支持。他也赞同，花点时间搞清楚自己想要什么更加重要。

之前和西北大学的某位前辈请教，问他关于读博的问题，他告所我说sec的PHD还是更看技术一些吧，gpa不要太低就好，说我可以直接申。但是今年是来不及辣，看明年咯，希望一些顺利！

item.title: Paper Reading Note - CHATAFL
item.description:
Actually, this work is very similar to my research direction in my internship project. I also think some ideas to use LLM to fuzz, but because my work ability and timeline, I haven’t finish my project yet. So, today I will summarize the good idea contributed from this paper.

Before Reading

Before diving into it, I have a few questions:

  • Where and how can LLM be applied to fuzzing?
    • In state transitions?
    • In testcase generation?
    • In mutation?
  • Regarding LLM:
    • Which LLM was used by the author?
    • Did the author fine-tune it?
    • If so, how was it fine-tuned?
  • Which protocol did the author research?
  • What are the cost and efficiency considerations?

With these questions in mind, I will begin my reading.

Start Reading

Abstract

Our protocol fuzzer CHATAFL constructs grammars for each message type in a protocol, and then mutates messages or predicts the next messages in a message sequence via interactions with LLMs. |

And the CHATAFL improve the coverage compare with NSFUZZ.

CHATAFL covers 47.60% and 42.69% more state transitions, 29.55% and 25.75% more states, and 5.81% and 6.74% more code, respectively.

INTRODUCTION

The concept of “LLM-guided protocol fuzzing”

  1. the fuzzer uses the LLM to extract a machine-readable grammar for a protocol that is used for structure-aware mutation
  2. the fuzzer uses the LLM to increase the diversity of messages in the recorded message sequences that are used as initial seeds.
  3. the fuzzer uses the LLM to break out of a coverage plateau, where the LLM is prompted to generate messages to reach new states.

Than the author compare the efficiency of chatafl with protocol fuzzer benchmark.

BACKGROUND AND MOTIVATION

Here, the author suggest some challenges

  1. (C1) Dependence on initial seeds. The effectiveness of mutation-based protocol fuzzers is severely limited by the provided initial seed inputs. The pre-recorded message sequences will hardly cover the great diversity of protocol states and input structures as discussed in the protocol specification.
  2. (C2) Unknown message structure. Without machinereadable information about the message structure, the fuzzer cannot make structurally interesting changes to the seed messages, e.g., to construct messages of unseen types or to remove, substitute, or add an entire, coherent data structure to a seed message.
  3. (C3) Unknown state space. Without machinereadable information about the state space, the fuzzer cannot identify the current state or be directed to explore previously unseen states.

Actually, what’s most appealing here is the solution for the “state,” the rest is just so so. Regarding the “state,” I need to find out which specific state the author is referring to later.

There are three state in Fuzzing

Next, let’s see the Motivation, here the author introduce their solutions for the three challenges mentioned above.

  1. Addressing seed dependence by having the LLM add a random message to a seed message sequence, with a focus on improving message diversity and validity (C1).
  2. Dealing with unknown message structures by requesting the LLM to provide machine-readable information about message grammar for various message types, with a focus on assessing the quality and coverage of these grammars compared to the ground truth (C2).
  3. Navigating the unknown state space by requesting the LLM to generate a message that leads to a new state, with an investigation into the effectiveness of this approach (C3).

How to tell LLM to generate, wondering to know!

CASE STUDY: TESTING THE CAPABILITIES OF LLMS FOR PROTOCOL FUZZING

Skip to the third part: Inducing Interesting State Transitions

We provide the LLM the message exchange between fuzzer and the protocol implementation and ask it to return a message that would lead to a new state. We evaluate how likely the message induce a transition to a new state. Specifically, we provide the LLM with existing communication history, enabling a server respectively to reach each state (i.e., INIT, READY, PLAY, and RECORD). Afterward, we query the LLM to determine the next client requests that can affect the server’s state. To mitigate the influence of the LLM’s stochastic behavior, we prompted the LLM 100 times for each state.

Actually, I had proposed the same idea before, but I hadn’t put it into practice because we selected a more complex target. Perhaps this event is educational for me. I should do some practices from the simplest target.

Perhaps considering how to minimize the LLM cost in algorithm design could also be a promising research direction?

LLM-GUIDED PROTOCOL FUZZING

A. Grammar-guided Mutation

1) Grammar Extraction

Here, the author use a method to generate message grammar called – in-context few-shot learning. Cool, this is a super idea!

In-context learning serves as an effective approach to fine-tuning the model. Few-shot learning is utilized to enhance the context with a few examples of desired inputs and outputs. This enables the LLM to recognize the input prompt syntax and output patterns.

2) Mutation based on Grammar

C. Surpassing Coverage Plateau

item.title: A diary in a special time
item.description:
My life and mental state

Today is Saturday, and I don’t want to overwhelm myself with work, even though I’m facing the most intense pressure I’ve ever experienced in my undergraduate years as I strive to secure a Master’s or PhD position.

Just yesterday, I gave a presentation for one of my courses. The teacher, an associate professor from Canada, transformed the presentation into a meaningful conversation. He offered a piece of advice that has left a lasting impact on me and provided valuable lessons. He emphasized the importance of always being prepared for a presentation and understanding the purpose at any given time. This advice is especially crucial when you’re planning to study abroad, as it’s easy to feel lost in a new environment. He humorously added, “In many years, you might forget my name and the name of the course, but you’ll remember being in a strange place, with an strange course and teacher, telling you to always be prepared and know your purpose.”

His words deeply resonated with me. Lately, I’ve been juggling various commitments, such as internships, preparing for the IELTS, and applying for Master’s programs. It’s been three months since I last wrote a blog or reflected on my life and studies.So today, I took a moment to sit down in my lab and write this blog to summarize the past few months of my work and life.

I’d like to share what I’ve been up to recently. Firstly, I’m still engrossed in my internship project focused on fuzzing at ISCAS. What’s more, I’m about to commence work with Professor Xing on the AIxCC competition, and I’m faced with three course projects that I must complete – it feels like quite a workload!

Additionally, this week I’ve prepared all the application materials for my UK university applications. I’m set to apply to the University of Southampton next Monday.

Furthermore, I’m in the process of deciding the direction for my bachelor’s thesis. I can use the progress I made in AIxCC competition as my bachelor’s thesis, but my school tutor also give my a direction about detecting encrypted malicious traffic.

On top of all this, my IELTS score currently stands at only 6. I need to put in the effort to improve it to 6.5 by the end of this year. And, I also have to obtain a GRE score this year! The NUS need GRE grade, cry!

Yes, there are just too many tasks on my plate.

Despite my initial intention to avoid discussing anything related to computer knowledge formally, I’ve found it difficult to do so. First, let me list all the tasks I need to complete:

  • Course projects
    • NLP course
    • CV course
    • AI Reach Practice
  • Internship project
  • IELTS
  • GRE
  • AIxCC competition
  • School applications (Personal Statement, Reference Letter, and so on…)

However, I want to make it clear that I’m not writing this blog to complain. My aim is to tackle these challenges one by one.

Some Research experiences

After that, I want to share some research experiences I’ve faced in the last few months. Perhaps I should list them for a clearer expression.

  1. You should divide your tasks into smaller, more manageable ones until you can.
  2. Many times, you may think you’ve found a paper that could solve your problems, but most of the time, you’ll find it couldn’t after some experimentation. This is a common occurrence, so keep on reading and trying.
  3. Writing a weekly summary, in my internship, it is called a “weekly report,” can make your project clearer, and perhaps you will get new ideas when you write it.
  4. Don’t always think you should wait until you are well-prepared to start. When you’re confused, what you should do is start. You can do five or more tasks, even if they are not well-prepared, instead of one task for which you’ve prepared everything well.

Hope everything goes smoothly afterwards!
